---
title: 'Why do those with long-term substance use disorders stop abusing substances:
  A qualitative study'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-UZU4VCUU" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Pettersen, H., Landheim, A., Skeie, I., Biong, S., Brodahl, M., Benson, V., &#38; Davidson, L. (2018). Why do those with long-term substance use disorders stop abusing substances: A qualitative study. <i>Substance Abuse: Research and Treatment</i>, <i>12</i>, 1–8. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1177/1178221817752678">https://doi.org/10.1177/1178221817752678</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-UZU4VCUU" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-UZU4VCUU" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Pettersen et al. conducted a study to understand why people with long-term substance use disorders (SUDs) decide to stop using substances. They interviewed 18 individuals who had been diagnosed with SUDs and had remained abstinent for at least five years. The study found that harmful consequences and significant events during substance use played a role in their decision to quit. Pressure and concern from family members were also crucial in their initial efforts to abstain. Imagining a different life and knowing about treatment options gave them hope and reinforced their motivation to stop using substances. Understanding these reasons can help improve treatment programs by addressing the specific motivations of individuals seeking help.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-UZU4VCUU" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Substance Use Disorders, Recovery, Decision Making, Abstinence, Treatment Options, Motivation
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-UZU4VCUU" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    Although a significant proportion of adults recover from substance use disorders (SUDs), little is known about how they reach this turning point or why they stop using. The purpose of the study was to explore the factors that influence reasoning and decision making about quitting substance use after a long-term SUD. Semistructured interviews were conducted with 18 participants, each of whom had been diagnosed with a SUD and had been abstinent for at least 5 years. A resource group of peer consultants in long-term recovery from SUDs contributed to the study’s planning, preparation, and initial analyses. Participants recalled harmful consequences and significant events during their years of substance use. Pressure and concern from close family members were important in their initial efforts to abstain from substance use. Being able to imagine a different life, and the awareness of existing treatment options, promoted hope and further reinforced their motivation to quit. Greater focus on why those with SUDs want to quit may help direct treatment matching; treatment completion may be more likely if the person’s reasons for seeking help are addressed.
  </article>
